results.title: Shaw versus Shakespeare. Part 1: the character of Caesar
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: George Bernard Shaw, played by Donald Moffatt, analyses Shakespear’s characterisation of Julis Caesar and compares it with his won treatment. Shaw claims the character of Caesar was beyind Shakespeare, but admits Shakespear is still the “King of the dramatists”.

results.title: Sharpening and tempering farm tools
results.brief_description: Explains how to treat carbon-steel tools for forge sharpening; how to sharpen, harden and temper a cultivator and a ploughshare shovel; how to identify tempering colours. From the series “Farm work forging”.

results.title: Sharkey's Party
results.brief_description: Sharky’s friends throw a wild party to celebrate his homecoming after six months of psychiatric treatment. This is a satirical look at friendship in the 1980s and the “sex and drugs and rock n roll” ethos.

results.title: Shark
results.creator_credit: Scott Ransom, Roone Arledge and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Presents some of the characteristics and habits of sharks in particular the white pointer, the tiger shark, and the bronze whaler. Peter Benchley, author of “Jaws”, guides us through the ancient times to sharks to modern day. They dive near Gladstone, in Queensland, a small fishing port on the East Coast of Australia, diving in the Barrier Reef; diving also takes place in South Australia, near Seal Island.

results.title: Shaping up: work and evaluation
results.creator_credit: Chris O'Rourke and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Representatives from IBM. Ansett, and Labtam discuss issues related to evaluation. Issues are: venture capital, risk taking, research and development, goal setting, qualitative surveys are described in relation to company objectives. Designed as an icebreker in initiating a discussion on evaluation in education.

results.title: Shaped By Danish hands
results.creator_credit: Hagen Hasselbalch, Government Film Committee of Denmark and Minerva Film
results.brief_description: Illustrates the work of Danish craftsmen in the making of pottery, furniture, toys, silverware, etc. Begins by showing ceramic workers making pottery and earthenware and then describes some of the experiments in design and in the use if new types of glazes by various artists. Examples of ceramic ware of the foremost artists in Denmark are shown. Prominent furniture designers are then shown at work and examples of designs of modern furniture, including types suitable for mass production are illustrated. Designs for wooden toys are shown too. Concludes by showing how artists plan new designs in silver and how silversmiths fashion articles from their designs.

results.title: Shakespeare out loud: Cicely Berry workshop [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Several prominent Australian actors take part in a workshop conducted by Cicely Berry OBE, Vocal Coach with the Royal Shakespeare Company for the past 30 years who has practiced her skills internationally with a diverse range of people. Attendees of the master class share what they’ve learnt from the experience and the effectiveness of working on the exercises in a group comprising of English and drama practitioners. Participants include: Barry Otto, Lucy Cornell, Olivia Pigeot, Belinda Bromilow, John Adam, Christopher Stollery, Peter Hambleton, Mary Docker, Peter Feeney.

results.title: Shakespeare is alive and well in the modern world
results.creator_credit: Barbara Winard and Centre for Humanities
results.brief_description: This interesting program is a very useful resource for students investigating the works of Shakespeare. It is structured in three parts and examines the treatment of alienation, love, revenge and humour in a discussion of “Romeo and Juliet” and “Hamlet”; ambition, violence and the nature of evil in “Macbeth” and rebellion and the power of words in “Julius Caesar”. By using footage from feature films, we see how the same themes have been treated in texts such as “Animal Farm”, “Mutiny on the Bounty” and “The Outsiders.”
results.title_for_label: Shakespeare is alive and well in the modern world

results.title: Shakespeare and Kronborg
results.brief_description: Kronborg Castle in Helsingor, the probable inspiration for Shakespeare’s “Hamlet”. Re-enacts a visit to the castle in 1600 by a group of English players, which Shakespeare may have accompanied, evokes the atmosphere of the castle and shows a Danish company in the annual summer performances of “Hamlet” in the castle courtyard. Script by Carl Theodor Dreyer.
